Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer err in refusing Mr. Randhawa's application for a work permit based on his inability to maintain hygiene standards?
Outcome: Allowed judicial review, quashed decision, remitted for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer doubted applicant's ability to maintain hygiene standards
Evidence_Type: Interview responses, experience and training records, on-the-job training potential
Basis_of_Claim: Unreasonable assessment by visa officer lacking expertise in food hygiene
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Visa officer's failure to consider relevant factors such as training and experience
Application_Error: Failure to consider on-the-job training and disregard of prior experience and training
Review_Outcome: Decision overturned, case remitted for re-evaluation
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's experience, training, and possibility of on-the-job training
Application_Factor: Ability to perform required work under IRPR
Outcome_of_Review: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Cause_of_Refusal: Perceived inability to maintain hygiene standards based on interview
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider available evidence on training and experience
Procedural_Fairness: Officer did not adequately consider all relevant factors
Credibility_Issues: Assessment of applicant's credibility regarding hygiene practices
Procedural_Issue: Lack of proper consideration of relevant factors in decision-making
Omission_Type: Failure to consider on-the-job training and professional background
